executive_summary: The personal waxing and nail salons industry has grown over the past five years despite the high interest rate environment experienced in the latter part of the period, which has negatively affected small businesses. However, rising disposable income and consumer spending have benefitted the industry and outweighed the negatives of high inflation. Revenue gains have been led by various product trends, including matte nails, colored gel nails and threading. Over the past five years, revenue has grown at a CAGR of 6.6% to $29.4 billion, including an expected 2.1% increase in 2024. Profit is expected to jump to 8.6% of revenue in 2024 from 8.5% in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Demand for Services has Benefitted the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry grew over much of the current five-year period because most consumers have continued to demand affordable luxuries, like manicures and waxing services. Nail salons have implemented membership clubs to cultivate customer loyalty. Nail art has become a mainstream way of expressing one's tastes and fashion sense.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The High Interest Rate Environment Has Limited Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The high interest rate environment has negatively affected small businesses, including industry establishments, specifically in the latter part of the period. High interest rates have limited spending on discretionary services. Despite this, industry revenue has grown due to the jump in consumer spending and disposable income.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry Profit Growth Attracts New Entrants and Leads to Industry Expansion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Profit margins have climbed due to demand for higher-value products and services, coupled with a jump in consumer spending and disposable income. The number of salons has increased due to low entry costs and rising revenue and profit. The number of establishments and employees has also grown to meet demand.

New product offerings like gel services and elaborate nail art have aided revenue growth. Gels tend to be more expensive than traditional manicures. Specialty manicures have blossomed as modes of self-expression.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Polished Lifestyles Will Benefit the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving economic conditions like increasing disposable income will fuel industry growth as consumers can spend more on discretionary higher-value services. However, an economic downturn from high interest rates can negatively impact demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New Entrants Will Seek to Take Advantage of Growing Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: An estimated one-third of salons offer full services, which is expected to grow. Despite lagging profit, demand for higher-margin products will attract new entrants. The industry will remain fragmented with a high share of non-employers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Environmental Concerns Will Impact Products Used
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Growing environmental awareness will lead salons to carry more eco-friendly, non-toxic products. Increased regulations are expected following exposure about harmful chemicals in some products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: High Interest Rates Will Initially Limit Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite expected Fed rate cuts, high interest rates at the start of the outlook period will negatively affect small businesses offering discretionary services, limiting revenue growth. However, rising disposable income will propel growth as consumers can afford more expensive services.

industry_definition: This industry comprises salons that primarily offer nonsurgical hair removal through body waxing and nail care services. This industry does not include companies that primarily offer hairstyling or training in cosmetic arts, nor does it include electrolysis, permanent makeup or tanning services.

negative_impact_factors: Low - Steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Price and customer loyalty are crucial forms of internal competition.
Nail salons offering lower prices, discounts and promotions will attract more customers.
Nail salons encounter external competition from drug stores that offer affordable nail care products for home use.
The industry has benefitted from new product offerings like gels and nail art which have driven revenue growth and profit margins.
New entrants are expected over the next five years to take advantage of growing demand.
Large nail salons establish near high-traffic areas to benefit from walk-in clients.
Larger salons expand by adding locations and offering waxing and nail services.
State regulations require licenses and accredited programs for employees.
Rising interest rates during the current period negatively impacted small businesses like nail salons.
The positive consumer trend toward gels has boosted industry profit.
Wages are a significant expense for the service-based industry.
Nail salons locate in regions with large populations to encounter more walk-ins.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Women over the age of 46 make up the largest market for the industry. One-third of revenue comes from selling services to this market segment. Clients within this age bracket often have established forms of income. As a result, they have the disposable income necessary to purchase a greater deal of value-added services.

Women between 36 and 45 years old make up the second-largest market for waxing and nail salons. This market comprises over one-fifth of industry revenue. On average, consumers in this age group spend $100.00 more on personal care items and services than the average US consumer.
Women between 26 to 35 years old represent the third largest market for the industry. This market comprises just under one-fifth of industry revenue.

Since consumers within this age group are beginning to enter the workforce, their discretionary income level is lower than other age groups. Consumers in this market are less likely to purchase expensive salon items. Consumers within this age group still make up a significant source of demand for personal care services, but they will more likely buy the more basic services.

Women in this market segment have lower disposable incomes than market segments of older women. Part of the reason for their lower market share is that consumers within this age bracket are more likely to purchase basic services because of their lower income levels.
Men represent a small but steady market segment for the industry. Many salons offer services specifically for men and a minimal but growing number of salons are even designed exclusively for males.

products_and_services.product_description: Pedicure services include cutting and shaping nails, removing cuticles and applying polish to the nails.
Manicure services include cutting and shaping nails, removing cuticles and applying polish to the nails.
Other nail services include polish change, callus treatment, broken nail repair, nail artwork, gel coating and buffing.
Waxing services are offered by operators and comprise a small share of revenue. This service segment includes both body waxing and facial waxing.
Merchandise sales are the smallest product segment in the industry. Merchandise sales move in line with consumer confidence and disposable income levels.

tier_1_suppliers: Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US
Beauty, Cosmetics & Fragrance Stores in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Cosmetic & Beauty Products Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industry's performance depends on active consumer spending. With more disposable income, consumers are more likely to purchase personal-care products and services like those offered in this industry.

Industry revenue growth is positively correlated with trends in per capita disposable income. When per capita disposable income rises, consumers have more money to spend on discretionary services like manicures, pedicures and waxing treatments.

The unemployment rate is inversely related to demand for industry products and services. When unemployment increases, clients are less likely to indulge in higher-value salon services because of decreased disposable income and a greater tendency to save.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic has the greatest share of industry establishments, accounting for over one-third of the nation's total. The states with the highest concentration of establishments in this region include New York and New Jersey. Companies locate salons near these major metropolitan centers because of the large consumer markets in the area. Companies typically choose to locate in high-traffic locations, near shopping malls, strip centers and department stores. The Mid-Atlantic region has a higher-than-average per capita income level. Businesses are more attracted to the region since consumers have more disposable income to spend on discretionary personal care services.

The West region has the second largest concentration of establishments, accounting for more than one-quarter of industry salons. The region is home to a large portion of the US population. Establishments in the West are dominated by California, which has the second-highest percentage of waxing and nail salons in the entire country. California is an attractive destination because of its large consumer markets in Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego. The West has higher per capita income than the rest of the nation, meaning consumers have more income to spend on discretionary services, like nail care and specialty waxing treatments.

The Southeast comprises the third-largest region of industry establishments. Population density in the Southeast has been growing over the past decade and the region is now home to a larger portion of the population. Greater migration toward the Southeast region makes it an attractive destination for industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators in the personal waxing and nail salons industry are subject to advertising and consumer protections. Specifically, salons are subject to advertising and consumer protection laws. Under federal and state law, ads that mislead or deceive consumers are unlawful. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) can take legal action if a salon's ads are misleading.

Typical zoning and real estate land-use restrictions also apply to salons. Landlords must obtain all necessary zoning approvals and permit for the site to be used as a retail establishment. Salons with franchise operations must also abide by the FTC's Trade Regulation Rule on Franchising. Franchisors must provide information about subjects like franchisor-initiated lawsuits against franchisees.

The majority of states have licensing requirements for nail and skin care technicians. Employees must complete a program in an accredited state-licensed cosmetology or esthetics (skincare) school. License qualifications vary by state, but a worker must typically have a high school diploma or GED, be at least 16 years old and have graduated from a state-licensed esthetics or cosmetology school. Education requirements vary widely by state.

To prevent the spread of the coronavirus, most state governments mandated nonessential businesses, which includes operators in this industry, to close in mid-March 2020 temporarily. To the industry's benefit, state governments have lifted the restrictions since, enabling salons to reopen as long as they comply with the social distancing mandates.

basis_points.basis_description: Price and customer loyalty are crucial forms of internal competition. Nail salons offering lower prices, special discounts and promotions will attract more customers.
Nail salons encounter external competition from drug stores that offer nail care products. These products are typically more affordable and can be applied at home.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly fragmented; nail salons are spread across many locations to be close to key consumer markets in high-traffic areas. This trend makes it difficult for one company to service a large portion of the entire market.
According to the latest data from the US Census Bureau, most nail salons operate from a single location and generate less than $250,000 each year.
Industry concentration has remained relatively steady. While major nail salons have expanded and added locations, this growth has not significantly changed the concentration of the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Typically, nail and waxing salons purchase items required for day to day operations such as nail polishes, acrylics, nail polish removers, gels, lotions, waxes, applicators and pads. Salons also purchase materials for resale. The majority of supplies are purchased at professional beauty supply stores as well as through online-only distributors.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGES JUMP AS OPERATORS SATISFY THE GROWING DEMAND FOR SERVICES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many employees work on a part-time basis. According to Nail Magazine, most nail technicians rent their booths from the salon, while less than one-quarter are employed directly by the salon. Under commission-based models, employees retain a specified percentage of their earnings. Under a booth-rental model, salon owners charge stylists a fixed fee for booth rentals.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Typical employees for salons include nail technicians, estheticians and management and administrative employees. Since estheticians and nail technicians must be licensed to work in salons, labor restrictions are a barrier to entry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue trends within the industry largely depend on per capita disposable income, changes in consumer sentiment and the unemployment rate. These factors particularly impact demand for value-added services and retail purchases from salons.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CONSUMER SPENDING ON DISCRETIONARY SERVICES IS LIMITED BY HIGH INTEREST RATES
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry has exhibited a very high level of revenue volatility due to high interest rates limiting consumer spending on discretionary services such as those offered by the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NAIL SALONS SHIFT TO MORE ECO-FRIENDLY PRODUCT OFFERINGS FOLLOWING GROWING ENVIRONMENTAL AWARENESS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nail salons have started offering products that don't contain harmful chemicals. These chemicals can be linked to headaches, dizziness and nausea. Nail salons that carry eco-friendly products will appeal more to consumers who are concerned about the environment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NAIL SALONS DIVERSIFY SERVICE OFFERINGS IN ESTABLISHMENTS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nail salons have offered more waxing services to diversify services. For example, threading has gained popularity and enables consumers to perform hair removal frequently. Threading has revitalized the industry. Threading is attractive to consumers with sensitive skin, unlike waxing, it does not remove a layer of skin.

FAQs.question: Do you market your company's services on e-commerce sites, such as Groupon, to generate sales?
FAQs.answer: Nail salons are offering an array of premium products and services, including shellac and color-changing shellac manicures.

FAQs.question: Are your sales reliant on the overall health of the US economy (i.e. consumer spending and per capita disposable income)?
FAQs.answer: As a service industry of personal care services, waxing and nail salons depend on positive economic conditions. When incomes are low, consumers may opt to paint their own nails at home or purchase at home waxing kits.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage operating expenses to ensure maximum profitability?
FAQs.answer: Wages represent the largest operating cost for salons.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in high-traffic areas to maximize visibility?
FAQs.answer: Location is very important to nail salons. Walk-ins constitute a major source of revenue so it is beneficial to be located in high-traffic areas.

FAQs.question: Does your salon leverage social media platforms, such as Instagram and Yelp, to establish a stronger market presence?
FAQs.answer: Influencers on social media, especially through reviews, are key to developing new marketing channels.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with customers?
FAQs.answer: Allowing clients to book services on a mobile application will entice a broader consumer base of younger clients as well as decrease human error by automating the booking process.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The increasing minimum wage benefits industry employees while increasing costs for operators.

FAQs.question: The largest companies in the industry are franchised, thus, specific laws pertinent to franchise-run companies apply. For example, operators must register as a franchisee and invest a certain amount of capital as well as ongoing fees to a franchisor.
How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Adding new value-added and premium services, including specialty nail art and gels that last longer, can benefit profit margins.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income and other macroeconomic drivers take negative turns, demand for industry services also declines.

FAQs.question: What is your level of business expertise? How can you improve your business management skills?
What do you do to promote loyalty and to keep your customers returning for follow-up visits? Do you offer a rewards program for loyal clients?
FAQs.answer: A satisfied client base will encourage repeat customers, which are the main component of clients.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a diverse range of services? Which services can you add to your portfolio?
FAQs.answer: Operators that develop a range of basic and specialty services and expertise reduce the effects of local price-based competition.

FAQs.question: Do you find revenue trends to be in line with changes in competition? How do you distinguish yourself from your competitors?
FAQs.answer: The industry faces contends with external competition from drug stores, hair salons and spas.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to adults aged 20-64? How can you tailor your services more to this segment?
FAQs.answer: Women within this age group are the largest source of demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising consumer spending? How will you prepare to meet this demand?
FAQs.answer: The industry's performance depends on active consumer spending.
